00026 =head1 NAME
00027 
00028 WeBWorK::PG::Translator - Evaluate PG code and evaluate answers safely
00029 
00030 =head1 SYNPOSIS
00031 
00032     my $pt = new WeBWorK::PG::Translator;      # create a translator;
00033     $pt->environment(\%envir);      # provide the environment variable for the problem
00034     $pt->initialize();              # initialize the translator
00035     $pt-> set_mask();               # set the operation mask for the translator safe compartment
00036     $pt->source_string($source);    # provide the source string for the problem
00037 
00038     $pt -> unrestricted_load("${courseScriptsDirectory}PG.pl");
00039     $pt -> unrestricted_load("${courseScriptsDirectory}dangerousMacros.pl");
00040                                     # load the unprotected macro files
00041                                     # these files are evaluated with the Safe compartment wide open
00042                                     # other macros are loaded from within the problem using loadMacros
00043 
00044     $pt ->translate();              # translate the problem (the out following 4 pieces of information are created)
00045     
00046     $PG_PROBLEM_TEXT_ARRAY_REF = $pt->ra_text();              # output text for the body of the HTML file (in array form)
00047     $PG_PROBLEM_TEXT_REF = $pt->r_text();                     # output text for the body of the HTML file
00048     $PG_HEADER_TEXT_REF = $pt->r_header;#\$PG_HEADER_TEXT;    # text for the header of the HTML file
00049     $PG_POST_HEADER_TEXT_REF = $pt->r_post_header
00050     $PG_ANSWER_HASH_REF = $pt->rh_correct_answers;            # a hash of answer evaluators
00051     $PG_FLAGS_REF = $pt ->rh_flags;                           # misc. status flags.
00052 
00053     $pt -> process_answers(\%inputs);    # evaluates all of the answers using submitted answers from %input
00054     
00055     my $rh_answer_results = $pt->rh_evaluated_answers;  # provides a hash of the results of evaluating the answers.
00056     my $rh_problem_result = $pt->grade_problem;         # grades the problem using the default problem grading method.
00057 
00058 =head1 DESCRIPTION
00059 
00060 This module defines an object which will translate a problem written in the Problem Generating (PG) language
00061 
00062 =cut
00063 
00064 =head2 be_strict
00065 
00066 This creates a substitute for C<use strict;> which cannot be used in PG problem
00067 sets or PG macro files.  Use this way to imitate the behavior of C<use strict;>
00068 
00069     BEGIN {
00070         be_strict(); # an alias for use strict.
00071                      # This means that all global variable
00072                      # must contain main:: as a prefix.
00073     }
00074 
00075 =cut
00076 
00077 BEGIN {
00078     # allows the use of strict within macro packages.
00079     sub be_strict {
00080         require 'ww_strict.pm';
00081         strict::import();
00082     }
00083     
00084     # also define in Main::, for PG modules.
00085     sub Main::be_strict { &be_strict }
00086 }
00087 
00088 =head2 evaluate_modules
00089 
00090     Usage:  $obj -> evaluate_modules('WWPlot', 'Fun', 'Circle');
00091             $obj -> evaluate_modules('reset');
00092 
00093 Adds the modules WWPlot.pm, Fun.pm and Circle.pm in the courseScripts directory to the list of modules
00094 which can be used by the PG problems.  The keyword 'reset' or 'erase' erases the list of modules already loaded
00095 
00096 =cut
00097 
00098 
00099 sub evaluate_modules {
00100     my $self = shift;
00101     my @modules = @_;
00102     local $SIG{__DIE__} = "DEFAULT"; # we're going to be eval()ing code
00103     foreach (@modules) {
00104         #warn "attempting to load $_\n";
00105         # ensure that the name is in fact a base name
00106         s/\.pm$// and warn "fixing your broken package name: $_.pm => $_";
00107         # call runtime_use on the package name
00108         # don't worry -- runtime_use won't load a package twice!
00109         #eval { runtime_use $_ };                   # 
00110         eval "package Main; require $_; import $_"; # change for WW1
00111         warn "Failed to evaluate module $_: $@" if $@;
00112         # record this in the appropriate place
00113         push @{$self->{ra_included_modules}}, "\%${_}::";
00114     }
00115 }
00116 #      old code for runtime_use
00117 #       if ( -r  "${courseScriptsDirectory}${module_name}.pm"   ) {
00118 #           eval(qq! require "${courseScriptsDirectory}${module_name}.pm";  import ${module_name};! );
00119 #           warn "Errors in including the module ${courseScriptsDirectory}$module_name.pm $@" if $@;
00120 #       } else {
00121 #           eval(qq! require "${module_name}.pm";  import ${module_name};! );
00122 #           warn "Errors in including either the module $module_name.pm or ${courseScriptsDirectory}${module_name}.pm $@" if $@;
00123 #       }
00124 =head2 load_extra_packages
00125 
00126     Usage:  $obj -> load_extra_packages('AlgParserWithImplicitExpand',
00127                                         'Expr','ExprWithImplicitExpand');
00128 
00129 Loads extra packages for modules that contain more than one package.  Works in conjunction with
00130 evaluate_modules.  It is assumed that the file containing the extra packages (along with the base
00131 pachage name which is the same as the name of the file minus the .pm extension) has already been
00132 loaded using evaluate_modules
00133 =cut
00134 
00135 sub load_extra_packages{
00136     my $self = shift;
00137     my @package_list = @_;
00138     my $package_name;
00139     
00140     foreach (@package_list) {
00141         # ensure that the name is in fact a base name
00142         s/\.pm$// and warn "fixing your broken package name: $_.pm => $_";
00143         # import symbols from the extra package
00144         import $_;
00145         warn "Failed to evaluate module $_: $@" if $@;
00146         # record this in the appropriate place
00147         push @{$self->{ra_included_modules}}, "\%${_}::";
00148     }
00149 }

00157 sub new {
00158     my $class = shift;
00159     my $safe_cmpt = new WWSafe; #('PG_priv');
00160     my $self = {
00161         preprocess_code           =>  \&default_preprocess_code,
00162         postprocess_code           => \&default_postprocess_code,
00163         envir                     => undef,
00164         PG_PROBLEM_TEXT_ARRAY_REF => [],
00165         PG_PROBLEM_TEXT_REF       => 0,
00166         PG_HEADER_TEXT_REF        => 0,
00167         PG_POST_HEADER_TEXT_REF   => 0,
00168         PG_ANSWER_HASH_REF        => {},
00169         PG_FLAGS_REF              => {},
00170         rh_pgcore                 => undef,    # ref to PGcore object
00171         safe                      => $safe_cmpt,
00172         safe_compartment_name     => $safe_cmpt->root,
00173         errors                    => "",
00174         source                    => "",
00175         rh_correct_answers        => {},
00176         rh_student_answers        => {},
00177         rh_evaluated_answers      => {},
00178         rh_problem_result         => {},
00179         rh_problem_state          => {
00180             recorded_score       => 0, # the score recorded in the data base
00181             num_of_correct_ans   => 0, # the number of correct attempts at doing the problem
00182             num_of_incorrect_ans => 0, # the number of incorrect attempts
00183         },
00184         rf_problem_grader         => \&std_problem_grader,
00185         rf_safety_filter          => \&safetyFilter,
00186         # ra_included_modules is now populated independantly of @class_modules:
00187         ra_included_modules       => [], # [ @class_modules ],
00188         #rh_directories            => {},
00189     };
00190     bless $self, $class;
00191 }

00246 
00247 # SHARE variables and routines with safe compartment
00248 # 
00249 # Some symbols are defined here (or in the IO module), and used inside the safe
00250 # compartment. Under WeBWorK 1.x, functions defined here had access to the
00251 # Global:: namespace, which contained course-specific data such things as
00252 # directory locations, the address of the SMTP server, and so on. Under WeBWorK
00253 # 2, there is no longer a global namespace. To get around this, IO functions
00254 # which need access to course-specific data are now defined in the IO.pl macro
00255 # file, which has access to the problem environment. Several entries have been
00256 # added to the problem environment to support this move.
00257 # 
00258 
00259 
00260 # Useful for timing portions of the translating process
00261 # The timer $WeBWorK::timer is defined in the module WeBWorK.pm
00262 # You must make sure that the code in that script for initialzing the 
00263 # timer is active.
00264 
00265 sub time_it {
00266     my $msg = shift;    
00267     $WeBWorK::timer->continue("PG macro:". $msg) if defined($WeBWorK::timer);
00268 }
00269 
00270 my %shared_subroutine_hash = (
00271     'time_it'                  => __PACKAGE__,
00272     '&PG_answer_eval'          => __PACKAGE__,
00273     '&PG_restricted_eval'      => __PACKAGE__,
00274     '&PG_macro_file_eval'       => __PACKAGE__,     
00275     '&be_strict'               => __PACKAGE__,
00276     '&PGsort'                  => __PACKAGE__,
00277     '&dumpvar'                 => __PACKAGE__,
00278     %WeBWorK::PG::IO::SHARE, # add names from WeBWorK::PG::IO and WeBWorK::PG::IO::*
00279 );

00281 sub initialize {
00282     my $self = shift;
00283     my $safe_cmpt = $self->{safe};
00284     #print "initializing safeCompartment",$safe_cmpt -> root(), "\n";
00285 
00286     $safe_cmpt -> share(keys %shared_subroutine_hash);
00287     no strict;
00288     local(%envir) = %{ $self ->{envir} };
00289     $safe_cmpt -> share('%envir');
00290     #local($rf_answer_eval) = sub { $self->PG_answer_eval(@_); };
00291     #local($rf_restricted_eval) = sub { $self->PG_restricted_eval(@_); };
00292     #$safe_cmpt -> share('$rf_answer_eval');
00293     #$safe_cmpt -> share('$rf_restricted_eval');
00294     use strict;
00295         
00296     $safe_cmpt -> share_from('main', $self->{ra_included_modules} );
00297         # the above line will get changed when we fix the PG modules thing. heh heh.
00298 }
00299 
00300 
00301 ################################################################
00302 #  Preloading the macro files
00303 ################################################################
00304 
00305 #  Preloading the macro files can significantly speed up the translation process.
00306 #  Files are read into a separate safe compartment (typically Safe::Root1::)
00307 #  This means that all non-explicit subroutine references and those explicitly prefixed by main::
00308 #  are prefixed by Safe::Root1::
00309 #  These subroutines (but not the constants) are then explicitly exported to the current
00310 #  safe compartment Safe::Rootx::
00311 
00312 #  Although they are not large, it is important to import PG.pl and dangerousMacros.pl into the 
00313 #  cached safe compartment as well.  This is because a call in PGbasicmacros.pl to NEW_ANSWER_NAME
00314 #  which is defined in PG.pl would actually be a call to Safe::Root1::NEW_ANSWER_NAME since
00315 #  PGbasicmacros is compiled into the SAfe::Root1:: compartment.  If PG.pl has only been compiled into
00316 #  the current Safe compartment, this call will fail.  There are many calls between PG.pl, dangerousMacros,
00317 #  PGbasicmacros and PGanswermacros so it is easiest to have all of them defined in Safe::Root1::
00318 #  There subroutines are still available in the current safe compartment.
00319 #  Sharing the hash %Safe::Root1:: in the current compartment means that any references to Safe::Root1::NEW_ANSWER_NAME
00320 #  will be found as long as NEW_ANSWER_NAME has been defined in Safe::Root1::
00321 #  
00322 #  Constants and references to subroutines in other macro files have to be handled carefully in preloaded files.
00323 #  For example a call to main::display_matrix (defined in PGmatrixmacros.pl) will become Safe::Root1::display_matrix and
00324 #  will fail since PGmatrixmacros.pl is loaded only into the current safe compartment Safe::Rootx::.  
00325 #  The value of main:: has to be evaluated at runtime in order to make this work.  Hence  something like
00326 #  my $temp_code  = eval('\&main::display_matrix');
00327 #  &$temp_code($matrix_object_to_be_displayed);
00328 # in PGanswermacros.pl
00329 #  would reference the run time value of main::, namely Safe::Rootx::
00330 #  There may be a clearer or more efficient way to obtain the runtime value of main::
00331 
00332 
00333 sub pre_load_macro_files {
00334     time_it("Begin pre_load_macro_files");
00335     my $self                = shift;
00336     my $cached_safe_cmpt    = shift;
00337     my $dirName             = shift;
00338     my @fileNameList        = @_;
00339     my $debugON             = 0;    # This helps with debugging the loading of macro files
00340 
00341 ################################################################
00342 #    prepare safe_cache
00343 ################################################################
00344     $cached_safe_cmpt -> share(keys %shared_subroutine_hash);
00345     no strict;
00346     local(%envir) = %{ $self ->{envir} };
00347     $cached_safe_cmpt -> share('%envir');
00348     use strict;
00349     $cached_safe_cmpt -> share_from('main', $self->{ra_included_modules} );
00350     $cached_safe_cmpt->mask(Opcode::full_opset());  # allow no operations
00351     $cached_safe_cmpt->permit(qw(   :default ));
00352     $cached_safe_cmpt->permit(qw(time));  # used to determine whether solutions are visible.
00353     $cached_safe_cmpt->permit(qw( atan2 sin cos exp log sqrt ));
00354 
00355     # just to make sure we'll deny some things specifically
00356     $cached_safe_cmpt->deny(qw(entereval));
00357     $cached_safe_cmpt->deny(qw (  unlink symlink system exec ));
00358     $cached_safe_cmpt->deny(qw(print require));
00359 
00360 ################################################################
00361 #    read in macro files
00362 ################################################################
00363 
00364     foreach my $fileName (@fileNameList)   {
00365         # determine whether the file has already been loaded by checking for
00366         # subroutine named _${macro_file_name}_init
00367         my $macro_file_name = $fileName;
00368         $macro_file_name =~s/\.pl//;  # trim off the extension
00369         $macro_file_name =~s/\.pg//;  # sometimes the extension is .pg (e.g. CAPA files)
00370         my $init_subroutine_name      = "_${macro_file_name}_init";
00371         my $macro_file_loaded = defined(&{$cached_safe_cmpt->root."::$init_subroutine_name"}) ? 1 : 0; 
00372     
00373         
00374         if ( $macro_file_loaded  )     {
00375             warn "$macro_file_name is already loaded" if $debugON;
00376          }else {
00377             warn "reading and evaluating $macro_file_name from $dirName/$fileName" if $debugON;
00378             ### read in file
00379             my $filePath = "$dirName/$fileName";
00380             local(*MACROFILE);
00381             local($/);
00382             $/ = undef;   # allows us to treat the file as a single line
00383             open(MACROFILE, "<$filePath") || die "Cannot open file: $filePath";
00384             my $string = <MACROFILE>;
00385             close(MACROFILE);
00386             
00387 
00388 ################################################################
00389 #    Evaluate macro files
00390 ################################################################
00391 #    FIXME  The following hardwired behavior should be modifiable
00392 #    either in the procedure call or in global.conf:
00393 # 
00394 #    PG.pl, IO.pl and dangerousMacros.pl are loaded without restriction
00395 #    All other files are loaded with restriction
00396 #     
00397             # construct a regex that matches only these three files safely
00398             my @unrestricted_files = (); #  no longer needed? FIXME w/PG.pl dangerousMacros.pl IO.pl/;
00399             my $unrestricted_files = join("|", map { quotemeta } @unrestricted_files);
00400             
00401             my $store_mask; 
00402             if ($fileName =~ /^($unrestricted_files)$/) {
00403                 $store_mask = $cached_safe_cmpt->mask();
00404                 $cached_safe_cmpt ->mask(Opcode::empty_opset());
00405             }           
00406             $cached_safe_cmpt -> reval('BEGIN{push @main::__eval__,__FILE__}; package main; ' .$string);
00407             warn "preload Macros: errors in compiling $macro_file_name:<br> $@" if $@;
00408             $self->{envir}{__files__}{$cached_safe_cmpt->reval('pop @main::__eval__')} = $filePath;
00409             if ($fileName =~ /^($unrestricted_files)$/) {
00410                 $cached_safe_cmpt ->mask($store_mask);
00411                 warn "mask restored after $fileName" if $debugON;
00412             }
00413             
00414 
00415         }
00416     }
00417     
00418 ################################################################################
00419 # load symbol table
00420 ################################################################################
00421     warn "begin loading symbol table "  if $debugON;
00422     no strict 'refs';
00423     my %symbolHash  = %{$cached_safe_cmpt->root.'::'};
00424     use strict 'refs';
00425     my @subroutine_names;
00426 
00427     foreach my $name (keys %symbolHash) {
00428         # weed out internal symbols
00429         next if $name =~ /^(INC|_|__ANON__|main::)$/;
00430         if ( defined(&{*{$symbolHash{$name}}})  )  {
00431 #               warn "subroutine $name" if $debugON;;
00432             push(@subroutine_names, "&$name");      
00433         }      
00434     }
00435     
00436     warn "Loading symbols into active safe compartment:<br> ", join(" ",sort @subroutine_names) if $debugON;
00437     $self->{safe} -> share_from($cached_safe_cmpt->root,[@subroutine_names]);
00438     
00439     # Also need to share the cached safe compartment symbol hash in the current safe compartment. 
00440     # This is necessary because the macro files have been read into the cached safe compartment
00441     # So all subroutines have the implied names  Safe::Root1::subroutine
00442     # When they call each other we need to make sure that they can reach each other
00443     # through the Safe::Root1 symbol table.
00444 
00445     $self->{safe} -> share('%'.$cached_safe_cmpt->root.'::');
00446     warn 'Sharing '.'%'. $cached_safe_cmpt->root. '::'  if $debugON;
00447     time_it("End pre_load_macro_files");
00448     # return empty string.
00449     '';
00450 }
00451 
00452 sub environment{
00453     my $self = shift;
00454     my $envirref = shift;
00455     if ( defined($envirref) )  {
00456         if (ref($envirref) eq 'HASH') {
00457             %{ $self -> {envir} } = %$envirref;
00458         } else {
00459             $self ->{errors} .= "ERROR: The environment method for PG_translate objects requires a reference to a hash";
00460         }
00461     }
00462     $self->{envir} ; #reference to current environment
00463 }

00471 sub mask {
00472     my $self = shift;
00473     my $mask = shift;
00474     my $safe_compartment = $self->{safe};
00475     $safe_compartment->mask($mask);
00476 }
00477 sub permit {
00478     my $self = shift;
00479     my @array = shift;
00480     my $safe_compartment = $self->{safe};
00481     $safe_compartment->permit(@array);
00482 }
00483 sub deny {
00484 
00485     my $self = shift;
00486     my @array = shift;
00487     my $safe_compartment = $self->{safe};
00488     $safe_compartment->deny(@array);
00489 }
00490 sub share_from {
00491     my $self = shift;
00492     my $pckg_name = shift;
00493     my $array_ref =shift;
00494     my $safe_compartment = $self->{safe};
00495     $safe_compartment->share_from($pckg_name,$array_ref);
00496 }
00497 
00498 sub source_string {
00499     my $self = shift;
00500     my $temp = shift;
00501     my $out;
00502     if ( ref($temp) eq 'SCALAR') {
00503         $self->{source} = $$temp;
00504         $out = $self->{source};
00505     } elsif ($temp) {
00506         $self->{source} = $temp;
00507         $out = $self->{source};
00508     }
00509     $self -> {source};
00510 }
00511 
00512 sub source_file {
00513     my $self = shift;
00514     my $filePath = shift;
00515     local(*SOURCEFILE);
00516     local($/);
00517     $/ = undef;   # allows us to treat the file as a single line
00518     my $err = "";
00519     if ( open(SOURCEFILE, "<$filePath") ) {
00520         $self -> {source} = <SOURCEFILE>;
00521         close(SOURCEFILE);
00522     } else {
00523         $self->{errors} .= "Can't open file: $filePath";
00524         croak( "Can't open file: $filePath\n" );
00525     }
00526 
00527 
00528 
00529     $err;
00530 }

00534 sub unrestricted_load {
00535     my $self = shift;
00536     my $filePath = shift;
00537     my $safe_cmpt = $self ->{safe};
00538     my $store_mask = $safe_cmpt->mask();
00539     $safe_cmpt->mask(Opcode::empty_opset());
00540     my $safe_cmpt_package_name = $safe_cmpt->root();
00541     
00542     my $macro_file_name = fileFromPath($filePath);
00543     $macro_file_name =~s/\.pl//;  # trim off the extenstion
00544     my $export_subroutine_name = "_${macro_file_name}_export";
00545     my $init_subroutine_name = "${safe_cmpt_package_name}::_${macro_file_name}_init";
00546 
00547     my $local_errors = "";
00548     no strict;
00549     #  warn "dangerousMacros main:: contains <br>\n  ".join("<br>\n ", %main::) if $debugON;
00550     my $init_subroutine  = eval { \&{$init_subroutine_name} };
00551     warn "No init routine for $init_subroutine_name: $@" if  $debugON and $@;
00552     use strict;
00553     my $macro_file_loaded = ref($init_subroutine) =~ /CODE/;
00554 
00555     #print STDERR "$macro_file_name   has not yet been loaded\n" unless $macro_file_loaded; 
00556     unless ($macro_file_loaded) {
00557         ## load the $filePath file
00558         ## Using rdo insures that the $filePath file is loaded for every problem, allowing initializations to occur.
00559         ## Ordinary mortals should not be fooling with the fundamental macros in these files.  
00560         my $local_errors = "";
00561         if (-r $filePath ) {
00562             my $rdoResult = $safe_cmpt->rdo($filePath);
00563             #warn "unrestricted load:  $filePath\n";
00564             $local_errors ="\nThere were problems compiling the file:\n $filePath\n $@\n" if $@;
00565             $self ->{errors} .= $local_errors if $local_errors;
00566             use strict;
00567         } else {
00568             $local_errors = "Can't open file $filePath for reading\n";
00569             $self ->{errors} .= $local_errors if $local_errors;
00570         }
00571         $safe_cmpt -> mask($store_mask);
00572         
00573     }
00574     # try again to define the initization subroutine
00575     $init_subroutine  = eval { \&{"$init_subroutine_name"} };
00576     $macro_file_loaded  = ref($init_subroutine) =~ /CODE/;
00577     if ( $macro_file_loaded ) {
00578 
00579             #warn "unrestricted load:  initializing $macro_file_name  $init_subroutine" ;
00580             &$init_subroutine();
00581     }
00582     $local_errors .= "\nUnknown error.  Unable to load $filePath\n" if ($local_errors eq '' and not $macro_file_loaded);
00583     #print STDERR "$filePath is properly loaded\n\n" if $macro_file_loaded;
00584     $local_errors;
00585 }
00586

00588     my $self = shift;
00589     $self->{safe}->root;
00590 }

00671 
00672 
00673 =head2  set_mask
00674 
00675 
00676 
00677 
00678 
00679 
00680 (e) Now we close the safe compartment.  Only the certain operations can be used
00681 within PG problems and the PG macro files.  These include the subroutines
00682 shared with the safe compartment as defined above and most Perl commands which
00683 do not involve file access, access to the system or evaluation.
00684 
00685 Specifically the following are allowed
00686 
00687     time()
00688         # gives the current Unix time
00689         # used to determine whether solutions are visible.
00690     atan, sin cos exp log sqrt
00691         # arithemetic commands -- more are defined in PGauxiliaryFunctions.pl
00692 
00693 The following are specifically not allowed:
00694 
00695     eval()
00696     unlink, symlink, system, exec
00697     print require
00698 
00699 
00700 
00701 =cut
00702 
00703 ##############################################################################
00704 
00705             ## restrict the operations allowed within the safe compartment
00706 
00707 sub set_mask {
00708     my $self = shift;
00709     my $safe_cmpt = $self ->{safe};
00710     $safe_cmpt->mask(Opcode::full_opset());  # allow no operations
00711     $safe_cmpt->permit(qw(   :default ));
00712     $safe_cmpt->permit(qw(time));  # used to determine whether solutions are visible.
00713     $safe_cmpt->permit(qw( atan2 sin cos exp log sqrt ));
00714 
00715     # just to make sure we'll deny some things specifically
00716     $safe_cmpt->deny(qw(entereval));
00717     $safe_cmpt->deny(qw (  unlink symlink system exec ));
00718     $safe_cmpt->deny(qw(print require));
00719 }
00720 
00721 ############################################################################
00722 
00723 =head2  PG_errorMessage
00724 
00725 This routine processes error messages by fixing file names and adding
00726 traceback information.  It loops through the function calls via
00727 caller() in order to give more information about where the error
00728 occurred.  Since the loadMacros() files and the .pg file itself are
00729 handled via various kinds of eval calls, the caller() information does
00730 not contain the file names.  So we have saved them in the
00731 $main::__files__ hash, which we look up here and use to replace the
00732 (eval nnn) file names that are in the caller stack.  We shorten the
00733 filenames by removing the templates or root directories when possible,
00734 so they are easier to read.
00735 
00736 We skip any nested calls to Parser:: or Value:: so that these act more like
00737 perl built-in functions.
00738 
00739 We stop when we find a routine in the WeBWorK:: package, or an __ANON__
00740 routine, in order to avoid reporting the PG translator calls that
00741 surround the pg file.  Finally, there is usually one more eval before
00742 that, so we remove it as well.
00743 
00744 File names are shortened, when possible, by replacing the templates
00745 directory with [TMPL], the WeBWorK root directory by [WW] and
00746 the PG root directory by [PG].
00747   
00748 =cut
00749 
00750 sub PG_errorMessage {
00751   my $return = shift; my $frame = 2; # return can be 'message' or 'traceback'
00752   my $message = join("\n",@_); $message =~ s/\.?\s+$//;
00753   my $files = eval ('$main::__files__'); $files = {} unless $files;
00754   my $tmpl = $files->{tmpl} || '$';
00755   my $root = $files->{root} || '$';
00756   my $pg   = $files->{pg}   || '$';
00757   #
00758   #  Fix initial message file names
00759   #
00760   $message =~ s! $tmpl! [TMPL]!g; $message =~ s! $root! [WW]!g; $message =~ s! $pg! [PG]!g;
00761   $message =~ s/(\(eval \d+\)) (line (\d+))/$2 of $1/;
00762   while ($message =~ m/of (?:file )?(\(eval \d+\))/ && defined($files->{$1})) {
00763     my $name = $files->{$1};
00764     $name =~ s!^$tmpl![TMPL]!; $name =~ s!^$root![WW]!; $name =~ s!^$pg![PG]!;
00765     $message =~ s/\(eval \d+\)/$name/g;
00766   }
00767   #
00768   #  Return just the message if that's all we want, or
00769   #   if the message already includes a stack trace
00770   #
00771   return $message."\n" if $return eq 'message' || $message =~ m/\n   Died within/;
00772   #
00773   #  Look through caller stack for traceback information
00774   #
00775   my @trace = ($message);
00776   my $skipParser = (caller(3))[3] =~ m/^(Parser|Value)::/;
00777   while (my ($pkg,$file,$line,$subname) = caller($frame++)) {
00778     last if ($subname =~ m/^(Safe::reval|main::__ANON__)/);
00779     next if $skipParser && $subname =~ m/^(Parser|Value)::/;  # skip Parser and Value calls
00780     next if $subname =~ m/__ANON__/;
00781     $file = $files->{$file} || $file;
00782     $file =~ s!^$tmpl![TMPL]!; $file =~ s!^$root![WW]!; $file =~ s!^$pg![PG]!;
00783     $message =  "   from within $subname called at line $line of $file";
00784     push @trace, $message; $skipParser = 0;
00785   }
00786   splice(@trace,1,1) while $trace[1] && $trace[1] =~ m/within \(eval\)/;
00787   pop @trace while $trace[-1] && $trace[-1] =~ m/within \(eval\)/;
00788   $trace[1] =~ s/   from/   Died/ if $trace[1];
00789   #
00790   #  report the full traceback
00791   #
00792   return join("\n",@trace,'');
00793 }
00794 
00795 =head2 PG_undef_var_check
00796 
00797 =pod
00798 
00799  Produces warnings of this type in order to help you guess which local variable is undefined
00800  Warning: Use of uninitialized value in concatenation (.) or string at mpu.cgi line 25.
00801  Possible variables are:
00802            '$GLOBAL_VARIABLE' => \'global',
00803            '$t' => \undef,
00804            '$s' => \'regular output'
00805  
00806 
00807 
00808 
00809 =cut
00810 
00811 sub PG_undef_var_check {
00812     if($_[0] !~ /^Use of uninitialized value/) {
00813         return @_;
00814     } else {
00815         # If there are objects, the output can be VERY large when you increase this
00816         local $Data::Dumper::Maxdepth = 2;
00817         # takes all lexical variables from caller-nemaspace
00818         my $possibles = Data::Dumper::Dumper({ %{PadWalker::peek_my(1)}, %{PadWalker::peek_our(1)} });
00819         
00820         $possibles ne "\$VAR1 = {};\n" ? ($possibles =~ s/^.*?\n(.*)\n.*?\n$/$1/ms) : ($possibles = '');
00821         return "Warning: " . join(', ', @_) . "Possible variables are:\n$possibles\n";
00822     }
00823 
00824 }
00825 ############################################################################
00826 
00827 =head2  Translate
00828 
00829 
00830 =cut
00831 
00832 sub translate {
00833     my $self = shift;
00834     my @PROBLEM_TEXT_OUTPUT = ();
00835     my $safe_cmpt = $self ->{safe};
00836     my $evalString = $self -> {source};
00837     $self ->{errors} .= qq{ERROR:  This problem file was empty!\n} unless ($evalString) ;
00838     $self ->{errors} .= qq{ERROR:  You must define the environment before translating.}
00839          unless defined( $self->{envir} );
00840     
00841     # install handlers for warn and die that call PG_errorMessage.
00842     # if the existing signal handler is not a coderef, the built-in warn or
00843     # die function is called. this does not account for the case where the
00844     # handler is set to "IGNORE" or to the name of a function. in these cases
00845     # the built-in function will be called.
00846     
00847     my $outer_sig_warn = $SIG{__WARN__};
00848     local $SIG{__WARN__} = sub {
00849         ref $outer_sig_warn eq "CODE"
00850             ? &$outer_sig_warn(PG_errorMessage('message', $_[0]))
00851             : warn PG_errorMessage('message', $_[0]);
00852     };
00853     
00854     my $outer_sig_die = $SIG{__DIE__};
00855     local $SIG{__DIE__} = sub {
00856         ref $outer_sig_die eq "CODE"
00857             ? &$outer_sig_die(PG_errorMessage('traceback', $_[0]))
00858             : die PG_errorMessage('traceback', $_[0]);
00859     };
00860 
00861 =pod
00862 
00863 (3) B<Preprocess the problem text>
00864 
00865 The input text is subjected to two global replacements.
00866 First every incidence of
00867 
00868     BEGIN_TEXT
00869     problem text
00870     END_TEXT
00871 
00872 is replaced by
00873 
00874     TEXT( EV3( <<'END_TEXT' ) );
00875     problem text
00876     END_TEXT
00877 
00878 The first construction is syntactic sugar for the second. This is explained
00879 in C<PGbasicmacros.pl>.
00880 
00881 Second every incidence
00882 of \ (backslash) is replaced by \\ (double backslash).  Third each incidence of
00883 ~~ is replaced by a single backslash.
00884 
00885 This is done to alleviate a basic
00886 incompatibility between TeX and Perl. TeX uses backslashes constantly to denote
00887 a command word (as opposed to text which is to be entered literally).  Perl
00888 uses backslash to escape the following symbol.  This escape
00889 mechanism takes place immediately when a Perl script is compiled and takes
00890 place throughout the code and within every quoted string (both double and single
00891 quoted strings) with the single exception of single quoted "here" documents.
00892 That is backlashes which appear in
00893 
00894     TEXT(<<'EOF');
00895     ... text including \{   \} for example
00896     EOF
00897 
00898 are the only ones not immediately evaluated.  This behavior makes it very difficult
00899 to use TeX notation for defining mathematics within text.
00900 
00901 The initial global
00902 replacement, before compiling a PG problem, allows one to use backslashes within
00903 text without doubling them. (The anomolous behavior inside single quoted "here"
00904 documents is compensated for by the behavior of the evaluation macro EV3.) This
00905 makes typing TeX easy, but introduces one difficulty in entering normal Perl code.
00906 
00907 The second global replacement provides a work around for this -- use ~~ when you
00908 would ordinarily use a backslash in Perl code.
00909 In order to define a carriage return use ~~n rather than \n; in order to define
00910 a reference to a variable you must use ~~@array rather than \@array. This is
00911 annoying and a source of simple compiler errors, but must be lived with.
00912 
00913 The problems are not evaluated in strict mode, so global variables can be used
00914 without warnings.
00915 
00916 
00917 
00918 =cut
00919 
00920 ############################################################################
00921 
00922 
00923             ##########################################
00924             ###### PG preprocessing code #############
00925             ##########################################
00926             
00927                 $evalString = &{$self->{preprocess_code}}($evalString);
00928 
00929              
00930 #               # default_preprocess_code
00931 #               # BEGIN_TEXT and END_TEXT must occur on a line by themselves.
00932 #               $evalString =~ s/\n\s*END_TEXT[\s;]*\n/\nEND_TEXT\n/g;
00933 #               $evalString =~ s/\n\s*BEGIN_TEXT[\s;]*\n/\nTEXT\(EV3\(<<'END_TEXT'\)\);\n/g;
00934 #               $evalString =~ s/ENDDOCUMENT.*/ENDDOCUMENT();/s; # remove text after ENDDOCUMENT
00935 #
00936 #               $evalString =~ s/\\/\\\\/g;    # \ can't be used for escapes because of TeX conflict
00937 #               $evalString =~ s/~~/\\/g;      # use ~~ as escape instead, use # for comments
00938 
00939 
00940 =pod
00941 
00942 (4) B<Evaluate the problem text>
00943 
00944 Evaluate the text within the safe compartment.  Save the errors. The safe
00945 compartment is a new one unless the $safeCompartment was set to zero in which
00946 case the previously defined safe compartment is used. (See item 1.)
00947 
00948 =cut
00949 
00950                 my ($PG_PROBLEM_TEXT_REF, $PG_HEADER_TEXT_REF, $PG_POST_HEADER_TEXT_REF,$PG_ANSWER_HASH_REF, $PG_FLAGS_REF, $PGcore)
00951                       =$safe_cmpt->reval("   $evalString");
00952                       
00953 
00954 # This section could use some more error messages.  In particular if a problem doesn't produce the right output, the user needs
00955 # information about which problem was at fault.
00956 #
00957 #
00958 
00959 #################
00960 # FIXME The various warning message tracks are still being sorted out
00961 # WARNING and DEBUG tracks are being handled elsewhere (in Problem.pm?)
00962 #################
00963                 $self->{errors} .= $@;
00964 
00965                 
00966 #               $self->{errors}.=join(CGI::br(), @{$PGcore->{WARNING_messages}} );
00967 #               $self->{errors}.=join(CGI::br(), @{$PGcore->{DEBUG_messages  }} );
00968 #######################################################################
00969 
00970 #               push(@PROBLEM_TEXT_OUTPUT   ,   split(/(\n)/,$$PG_PROBLEM_TEXT_REF)  ) if  defined($$PG_PROBLEM_TEXT_REF  );
00971                 push(@PROBLEM_TEXT_OUTPUT   ,   split(/^/,$$PG_PROBLEM_TEXT_REF)  ) if  ref($PG_PROBLEM_TEXT_REF  ) eq 'SCALAR';
00972                                                                                  ## This is better than using defined($$PG_PROBLEM_TEXT_REF)
00973                                                                                  ## Because more pleasant feedback is given
00974                                                                                  ## when the problem doesn't render.
00975                  # try to get the \n to appear at the end of the line
00976 
00977         use strict;
00978         #############################################################################
00979         ##########  end  EVALUATION code                                  ###########
00980         #############################################################################
00981 
00982             ##########################################
00983             ###### PG postprocessing code #############
00984             ##########################################
00985             $PG_PROBLEM_TEXT_REF = &{$self->{postprocess_code}}($PG_PROBLEM_TEXT_REF);
00986 
00987 
00988 =pod
00989 
00990 (5) B<Process errors>
00991 
00992 The error provided by Perl
00993 is truncated slightly and returned. In the text
00994 string which would normally contain the rendered problem.
00995 
00996 The original text string is given line numbers and concatenated to
00997 the errors.
00998 
00999 =cut
01000 
01001 
01002 
01003         ##########################################
01004         ###### PG error processing code ##########
01005         ##########################################
01006         my (@input,$lineNumber,$line);
01007         if ($self -> {errors}) {
01008                 #($self -> {errors}) =~ s/</&lt/g;
01009                 #($self -> {errors}) =~ s/>/&gt/g;
01010            #try to clean up errors so they will look ok
01011                 $self ->{errors} =~ s/\[[^\]]+?\] [^ ]+?\.pl://gm;   #erase [Fri Dec 31 12:58:30 1999] processProblem7.pl:
01012                 #$self -> {errors} =~ s/eval\s+'(.|[\n|r])*$//;
01013             #end trying to clean up errors so they will look ok
01014 
01015 
01016                 push(@PROBLEM_TEXT_OUTPUT   ,  qq!\n<A NAME="problem! .
01017                     $self->{envir} ->{'probNum'} .
01018                     qq!"><PRE>        Problem!.
01019                     $self->{envir} ->{'probNum'}.
01020                     qq!\nERROR caught by Translator while processing problem file:! .
01021                     $self->{envir}->{'probFileName'}.
01022                     "\n****************\r\n" .
01023                     $self -> {errors}."\r\n" .
01024                     "****************<BR>\n");
01025 
01026                push(@PROBLEM_TEXT_OUTPUT   , "------Input Read\r\n");
01027                $self->{source} =~ s/</&lt;/g;
01028                @input=split("\n", $self->{source});
01029                $lineNumber = 1;
01030                 foreach $line (@input) {
01031                     chomp($line);
01032                     push(@PROBLEM_TEXT_OUTPUT, "$lineNumber\t\t$line\r\n");
01033                     $lineNumber ++;
01034                 }
01035                 push(@PROBLEM_TEXT_OUTPUT  ,"\n-----<BR></PRE>\r\n");
01036 
01037 
01038 
01039         }
01040 
01041 =pod
01042 
01043 (6) B<Prepare return values>
01044 
01045     Returns:
01046             $PG_PROBLEM_TEXT_ARRAY_REF -- Reference to a string containing the rendered text.
01047             $PG_HEADER_TEXT_REF -- Reference to a string containing material to placed in the header (for use by JavaScript)
01048             $PG_POST_HEADER_TEXT_REF -- Reference to a string containing material to placed in body above form (for use by Sage)
01049             $PG_ANSWER_HASH_REF -- Reference to an array containing the answer evaluators.
01050             $PG_FLAGS_REF -- Reference to a hash containing flags and other references:
01051                 'error_flag' is set to 1 if there were errors in rendering
01052             $PGcore -- the PGcore object
01053 
01054 =cut
01055 
01056         ## we need to make sure that the other output variables are defined
01057 
01058                 ## If the eval failed with errors, one or more of these variables won't be defined.
01059                 $PG_ANSWER_HASH_REF = {}      unless defined($PG_ANSWER_HASH_REF);
01060                 $PG_HEADER_TEXT_REF = \( "" ) unless defined($PG_HEADER_TEXT_REF);
01061                 $PG_POST_HEADER_TEXT_REF = \( "" ) unless defined($PG_POST_HEADER_TEXT_REF);
01062                 $PG_FLAGS_REF = {}            unless defined($PG_FLAGS_REF);
01063 
01064                 $PG_FLAGS_REF->{'error_flag'} = 1     if $self -> {errors};
01065         my $PG_PROBLEM_TEXT                     = join("",@PROBLEM_TEXT_OUTPUT);
01066 
01067 
01068         $self ->{ PG_PROBLEM_TEXT_REF   }       = \$PG_PROBLEM_TEXT;
01069         $self ->{ PG_PROBLEM_TEXT_ARRAY_REF }   = \@PROBLEM_TEXT_OUTPUT;
01070         $self ->{ PG_HEADER_TEXT_REF    }       = $PG_HEADER_TEXT_REF;
01071         $self ->{ PG_POST_HEADER_TEXT_REF   }   = $PG_POST_HEADER_TEXT_REF;
01072         $self ->{ rh_correct_answers    }       = $PG_ANSWER_HASH_REF;
01073         $self ->{ PG_FLAGS_REF          }       = $PG_FLAGS_REF;
01074         $self ->{ rh_pgcore             }       = $PGcore;
01075         
01076         #warn "PGcore is ", ref($PGcore), " in Translator";
01077         #$self ->{errors};
01078 }  # end translate
01079 
01080 
01081 =head2   Answer evaluation methods
01082

01086 
01087     $obj->rh_student_answers

01093 sub rh_evaluated_answers {
01094     my $self = shift;
01095     my @in = @_;
01096     return $self->{rh_evaluated_answers} if @in == 0;
01097 
01098     if ( ref($in[0]) eq 'HASH' ) {
01099         $self->{rh_evaluated_answers} = { %{ $in[0] } }; # store a copy of the hash
01100     } else {
01101         $self->{rh_evaluated_answers} = { @in }; # store a copy of the hash
01102     }
01103     $self->{rh_evaluated_answers};
01104 }

01112     } else {

01114     }

01121

01130 
01131 =head3 process_answers
01132 
01133 
01134     $obj->process_answers()
01135 
01136 
01137 =cut
01138 
01139 
01140 sub process_answers{
01141     my $self = shift;
01142     my @in = @_;
01143     my %h_student_answers;
01144     if (ref($in[0]) eq 'HASH' ) {
01145         %h_student_answers = %{ $in[0] };  #receiving a reference to a hash of answers
01146     } else {
01147         %h_student_answers = @in;          # receiving a hash of answers
01148     }
01149     my $rh_correct_answers = $self->rh_correct_answers();
01150     my @answer_entry_order = ( defined($self->{PG_FLAGS_REF}->{ANSWER_ENTRY_ORDER}) ) ?
01151                           @{$self->{PG_FLAGS_REF}->{ANSWER_ENTRY_ORDER}} : keys %{$rh_correct_answers};
01152 
01153     # define custom warn/die handlers for answer evaluation. these used to be inside
01154     # the foreach loop around the conditional involving $rf_fun, but for efficiency
01155     # we've moved it out here. This means that the handlers will be active during the
01156     # code before and after the actual answer evaluation.
01157     
01158     my $outer_sig_warn = $SIG{__WARN__};
01159     local $SIG{__WARN__} = sub {
01160         ref $outer_sig_warn eq "CODE"
01161             ? &$outer_sig_warn(PG_errorMessage('message', $_[0]))
01162             : warn PG_errorMessage('message', $_[0]);
01163     };
01164     
01165     # the die handler is a closure over %errorTable and $outer_sig_die.
01166     # 
01167     # %errorTable accumulates a "full" error message for each error that occurs during
01168     # answer evaluation. then, right after the evaluation (which is done within a call
01169     # to Safe::reval), $@ is checked and it's value is looked up in %errorTable to get
01170     # the full error to report.
01171     # 
01172     # my question: why is this a hash? this is die, so once one occurs, we exit the reval.
01173     # wouldn't it be sufficient to have a scalar like $backtrace_for_last_error?
01174     # 
01175     # Note that %errorTable is cleared for each answer.
01176     my %errorTable;
01177     my $outer_sig_die = $SIG{__DIE__};
01178     local $SIG{__DIE__} = sub {
01179         
01180         # this chunk taken from dpvc's original handler
01181         my $fullerror = PG_errorMessage('traceback', @_);
01182         my ($error,$traceback) = split /\n/, $fullerror, 2;
01183         $fullerror =~ s/\n   /<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;/g; $fullerror =~ s/\n/<BR>/g;
01184         $error .= "\n";
01185         $errorTable{$error} = $fullerror;
01186         # end of dpvc's original code
01187         
01188         ref $outer_sig_die eq "CODE"
01189             ? &$outer_sig_die($error)
01190             : die $error;
01191     };
01192     
01193     # apply each instructors answer to the corresponding student answer
01194     
01195     foreach my $ans_name ( @answer_entry_order ) {
01196         my ($ans, $errors) = $self->filter_answer( $h_student_answers{$ans_name} );
01197         no strict;
01198         # evaluate the answers inside the safe compartment.
01199         local($rf_fun,$temp_ans) = (undef,undef);
01200         if ( defined($rh_correct_answers ->{$ans_name} ) ) {
01201             $rf_fun  = $rh_correct_answers->{$ans_name};
01202         } else {
01203             warn "There is no answer evaluator for the question labeled $ans_name";
01204         }
01205         $temp_ans  = $ans;
01206         $temp_ans = '' unless defined($temp_ans); #make sure that answer is always defined
01207                                                   # in case the answer evaluator forgets to check
01208         $self->{safe}->share('$rf_fun','$temp_ans');
01209         
01210         # clear %errorTable for each problem
01211         %errorTable = (); # is the error table being used? perhaps by math objects?
01212         
01213         my $rh_ans_evaluation_result;
01214         if (ref($rf_fun) eq 'CODE' ) {
01215             $rh_ans_evaluation_result = $self->{safe} ->reval( '&{ $rf_fun }($temp_ans, ans_label => \''.$ans_name.'\')' ) ;
01216             warn "Error in Translator.pm::process_answers: Answer $ans_name: |$temp_ans|\n $@\n" if $@;
01217         } elsif (ref($rf_fun) =~ /AnswerEvaluator/)   {
01218             $rh_ans_evaluation_result = $self->{safe} ->reval('$rf_fun->evaluate($temp_ans, ans_label => \''.$ans_name.'\')');
01219             $@ = $errorTable{$@} if $@ && defined($errorTable{$@});  #Are we redefining error messages here?
01220             warn "Error in Translator.pm::process_answers: Answer $ans_name: |$temp_ans|\n $@\n" if $@;
01221             warn "Evaluation error: Answer $ans_name:<BR>\n", 
01222                 $rh_ans_evaluation_result->error_flag(), " :: ",
01223                 $rh_ans_evaluation_result->error_message(),"<BR>\n" 
01224                     if defined($rh_ans_evaluation_result)  
01225                         and defined($rh_ans_evaluation_result->error_flag());
01226         } else {
01227             warn "Error in Translator.pm::process_answers: Answer $ans_name:<BR>\n Unrecognized evaluator type |", ref($rf_fun), "|";
01228         }   
01229         
01230         use strict;
01231         unless ( ( ref($rh_ans_evaluation_result) eq 'HASH') or ( ref($rh_ans_evaluation_result) eq 'AnswerHash') ) {
01232             warn "Error in Translator.pm::process_answers: Answer $ans_name:<BR>\n
01233                 Answer evaluators must return a hash or an AnswerHash type, not type |", 
01234                 ref($rh_ans_evaluation_result), "|";
01235         }
01236         $rh_ans_evaluation_result ->{ans_message} .= "$errors \n" if $errors;
01237         $rh_ans_evaluation_result ->{ans_name} = $ans_name;
01238         $self->{rh_evaluated_answers}->{$ans_name} = $rh_ans_evaluation_result;
01239     }
01240     $self->rh_evaluated_answers;
01241 }
01242 
01243 
01244 
01245 =head3 grade_problem
01246 
01247     $obj->rh_problem_state(%problem_state);  # sets the current problem state
01248     $obj->grade_problem(%form_options);
01249 
01250 
01251 =cut
01252

01254 sub grade_problem {
01255     my $self = shift;
01256     no strict;
01257     local %rf_options = @_;
01258     local $rf_grader = $self->{rf_problem_grader};
01259     local $rh_answers = $self->{rh_evaluated_answers};
01260     local $rh_state = $self->{rh_problem_state};
01261     $self->{safe}->share('$rf_grader','$rh_answers','$rh_state','%rf_options');
01262 ############################################
01263 #
01264 # FIXME
01265 # warning messages are not being transmitted from this evaluation
01266 # ??????
01267 ############################################
01268 
01269     ($self->{rh_problem_result},$self->{rh_problem_state}) =
01270         $self->{safe}->reval('&{$rf_grader}($rh_answers,$rh_state,%rf_options)');
01271     use strict;
01272     die $@ if $@;
01273     ($self->{rh_problem_result}, $self->{rh_problem_state});
01274 }

01276 sub rf_std_problem_grader {
01277     my $self = shift;
01278     return \&std_problem_grader;
01279 }
01280 sub old_std_problem_grader{
01281     my $rh_evaluated_answers = shift;
01282     my %flags = @_;  # not doing anything with these yet
01283     my %evaluated_answers = %{$rh_evaluated_answers};
01284     my  $allAnswersCorrectQ=1;
01285     foreach my $ans_name (keys %evaluated_answers) {
01286     # I'm not sure if this check is really useful.
01287         if (ref($evaluated_answers{$ans_name} ) eq 'HASH' ) {
01288             $allAnswersCorrectQ = 0 unless( 1 == $evaluated_answers{$ans_name}->{score} );
01289         } else {
01290             warn "Error: Answer $ans_name is not a hash";
01291             warn "$evaluated_answers{$ans_name}";
01292         }
01293     }
01294     # Notice that "all answers are correct" if there are no questions.
01295     { score             => $allAnswersCorrectQ,
01296       prev_tries        => 0,
01297       partial_credit    => $allAnswersCorrectQ,
01298       errors            =>  "",
01299       type              => 'old_std_problem_grader',
01300       flags             => {}, # not doing anything with these yet
01301     };  # hash output
01302 
01303 }
01304 
01305 #####################################
01306 # This is a model for plug-in problem graders
01307 #####################################
01308 
01309 sub std_problem_grader{
01310     my $rh_evaluated_answers = shift;
01311     my $rh_problem_state = shift;
01312     my %form_options = @_;
01313     my %evaluated_answers = %{$rh_evaluated_answers};
01314     #  The hash $rh_evaluated_answers typically contains:
01315     #      'answer1' => 34, 'answer2'=> 'Mozart', etc.
01316 
01317     # By default the  old problem state is simply passed back out again.
01318     my %problem_state = %$rh_problem_state;
01319 
01320 
01321     # %form_options might include
01322     # The user login name
01323     # The permission level of the user
01324     # The studentLogin name for this psvn.
01325     # Whether the form is asking for a refresh or is submitting a new answer.
01326 
01327     # initial setup of the answer
01328     my %problem_result = ( score                => 0,
01329                            errors               => '',
01330                            type                 => 'std_problem_grader',
01331                            msg                  => '',
01332                          );
01333     # Checks
01334 
01335     my $ansCount = keys %evaluated_answers;  # get the number of answers
01336     unless ($ansCount > 0 ) {
01337         $problem_result{msg} = "This problem did not ask any questions.";
01338         return(\%problem_result,\%problem_state);
01339     }
01340 
01341     if ($ansCount > 1 ) {
01342         $problem_result{msg} = 'In order to get credit for this problem all answers must be correct.' ;
01343     }
01344 
01345     unless (defined( $form_options{answers_submitted}) and $form_options{answers_submitted} == 1) {
01346         return(\%problem_result,\%problem_state);
01347     }
01348 
01349     my  $allAnswersCorrectQ=1;
01350     foreach my $ans_name (keys %evaluated_answers) {
01351     # I'm not sure if this check is really useful.
01352         if ( ( ref($evaluated_answers{$ans_name} ) eq 'HASH' ) or ( ref($evaluated_answers{$ans_name}) eq 'AnswerHash' ) ) {
01353             $allAnswersCorrectQ = 0 unless( 1 == $evaluated_answers{$ans_name}->{score} );
01354         } else {
01355             warn "Error: Answer $ans_name is not a hash";
01356             warn "$evaluated_answers{$ans_name}";
01357             warn "This probably means that the answer evaluator is for this answer is not working correctly.";
01358             $problem_result{error} = "Error: Answer $ans_name is not a hash: $evaluated_answers{$ans_name}";
01359         }
01360     }
01361     # report the results
01362     $problem_result{score} = $allAnswersCorrectQ;
01363 
01364     # I don't like to put in this bit of code.
01365     # It makes it hard to construct error free problem graders
01366     # I would prefer to know that the problem score was numeric.
01367     unless ($problem_state{recorded_score} =~ /^([+-]?)(?=\d|\.\d)\d*(\.\d*)?([Ee]([+-]?\d+))?$/ ) {
01368         $problem_state{recorded_score} = 0;  # This gets rid of non-numeric scores
01369     }
01370     #
01371     if ($allAnswersCorrectQ == 1 or $problem_state{recorded_score} == 1) {
01372         $problem_state{recorded_score} = 1;
01373     } else {
01374         $problem_state{recorded_score} = 0;
01375     }
01376 
01377     $problem_state{num_of_correct_ans}++ if $allAnswersCorrectQ == 1;
01378     $problem_state{num_of_incorrect_ans}++ if $allAnswersCorrectQ == 0;
01379     (\%problem_result, \%problem_state);
01380 }
01381 sub rf_avg_problem_grader {
01382     my $self = shift;
01383     return \&avg_problem_grader;
01384 }
01385 sub avg_problem_grader{
01386     my $rh_evaluated_answers = shift;
01387     my $rh_problem_state = shift;
01388     my %form_options = @_;
01389     my %evaluated_answers = %{$rh_evaluated_answers};
01390     #  The hash $rh_evaluated_answers typically contains:
01391     #      'answer1' => 34, 'answer2'=> 'Mozart', etc.
01392 
01393     # By default the  old problem state is simply passed back out again.
01394     my %problem_state = %$rh_problem_state;
01395 
01396 
01397     # %form_options might include
01398     # The user login name
01399     # The permission level of the user
01400     # The studentLogin name for this psvn.
01401     # Whether the form is asking for a refresh or is submitting a new answer.
01402 
01403     # initial setup of the answer
01404     my  $total=0;
01405     my %problem_result = (
01406         score => 0,
01407         errors => '',
01408         type => 'avg_problem_grader',
01409         msg => '',
01410     );
01411     my $count = keys %evaluated_answers;
01412     $problem_result{msg} = 'You can earn partial credit on this problem.' if $count >1;
01413     # Return unless answers have been submitted
01414     unless ($form_options{answers_submitted} == 1) {
01415         return(\%problem_result,\%problem_state);
01416     }
01417     # Answers have been submitted -- process them.
01418     foreach my $ans_name (keys %evaluated_answers) {
01419         $total += $evaluated_answers{$ans_name}->{score};
01420     }
01421     # Calculate score rounded to three places to avoid roundoff problems
01422     $problem_result{score} = ($count) ? $total/$count : 0 ; # give zero if no answers have been evaluated.
01423     # increase recorded score if the current score is greater.
01424     $problem_state{recorded_score}=0 unless defined $problem_state{recorded_score};
01425     $problem_state{recorded_score} = $problem_result{score} if $problem_result{score} > $problem_state{recorded_score};
01426 
01427 
01428     $problem_state{num_of_correct_ans}++ if $total == $count;
01429     $problem_state{num_of_incorrect_ans}++ if $total < $count ;
01430     warn "Error in grading this problem the total $total is larger than $count" if $total > $count;
01431     (\%problem_result, \%problem_state);
01432 
01433 }
01434 =head3 safetyFilter
01435 
01436     ($filtered_ans, $errors) = $obj ->filter_ans($ans)
01437                                $obj ->rf_safety_filter()
01438 
01439 =cut
01440 
01441 sub filter_answer {
01442     my $self = shift;
01443     my $ans = shift;
01444     my @filtered_answers;
01445     my $errors='';
01446     if (ref($ans) eq 'ARRAY') {   #handle the case where the answer comes from several inputs with the same name
01447                                   # In many cases this will be passed as a reference to an array
01448                                   # if it is passed as a single string (separated by \0 characters) as 
01449                                   # some early versions of CGI behave, then 
01450                                   # it is unclear what will happen when the answer is filtered.
01451         foreach my $item (@{$ans}) {
01452             my ($filtered_ans, $error) = &{ $self->{rf_safety_filter} } ($item);
01453             push(@filtered_answers, $filtered_ans);
01454             $errors .= " ". $error if $error;  # add error message if error is non-zero.
01455         }
01456         (\@filtered_answers,$errors);
01457     
01458     } else {
01459         &{ $self->{rf_safety_filter} } ($ans);
01460     }
01461     
01462 }
01463 sub rf_safety_filter {
01464     my $self = shift;
01465     my $rf_filter = shift;
01466     $self->{rf_safety_filter} = $rf_filter if $rf_filter and ref($rf_filter) eq 'CODE';
01467     warn "The safety_filter must be a reference to a subroutine" unless ref($rf_filter) eq 'CODE' ;
01468     $self->{rf_safety_filter}
01469 }
01470 sub safetyFilter {
01471         my $answer = shift;  # accepts one answer and checks it
01472         my $submittedAnswer = $answer;
01473         $answer = '' unless defined $answer;
01474         my ($errorno);
01475         $answer =~ tr/\000-\037/ /;
01476    #### Return if answer field is empty ########
01477         unless ($answer =~ /\S/) {
01478 #           $errorno = "<BR>No answer was submitted.";
01479             $errorno = 0;  ## don't report blank answer as error
01480 
01481             return ($answer,$errorno);
01482             }
01483    ######### replace ^ with **    (for exponentiation)
01484    #    $answer =~ s/\^/**/g;
01485    ######### Return if  forbidden characters are found
01486         unless ($answer =~ /^[a-zA-Z0-9_\-\+ \t\/@%\*\.\n^\(\)]+$/ )  {
01487             $answer =~ tr/a-zA-Z0-9_\-\+ \t\/@%\*\.\n^\(\)/#/c;
01488             $errorno = "<BR>There are forbidden characters in your answer: $submittedAnswer<BR>";
01489 
01490             return ($answer,$errorno);
01491             }
01492 
01493         $errorno = 0;
01494         return($answer, $errorno);
01495 }
01496 
01497 ##   Check submittedAnswer for forbidden characters, etc.
01498 #     ($submittedAnswer,$errorno) = safetyFilter($submittedAnswer);
01499 #       $errors .= "No answer was submitted.<BR>" if $errorno == 1;
01500 #       $errors .= "There are forbidden characters in your answer: $submittedAnswer<BR>" if $errorno ==2;
01501 #
01502 ##   Check correctAnswer for forbidden characters, etc.
01503 #     unless (ref($correctAnswer) ) {  #skip check if $correctAnswer is a function
01504 #       ($correctAnswer,$errorno) = safetyFilter($correctAnswer);
01505 #       $errors .= "No correct answer is given in the statement of the problem.
01506 #                   Please report this to your instructor.<BR>" if $errorno == 1;
01507 #       $errors .= "There are forbidden characters in the problems answer.
01508 #                   Please report this to your instructor.<BR>" if $errorno == 2;
01509 #     }

01513 =head2 PGsort
01514 
01515 Because of the way sort is optimized in Perl, the symbols $a and $b
01516 have special significance.
01517 
01518 C<sort {$a<=>$b} @list>
01519 C<sort {$a cmp $b} @list>
01520 
01521 sorts the list numerically and lexically respectively. 
01522 
01523 If C<my $a;> is used in a problem, before the sort routine is defined in a macro, then
01524 things get badly confused.  To correct this the macro PGsort is defined below.  It is 
01525 evaluated before the problem template is read.  In PGbasicmacros.pl, the two subroutines
01526 
01527     PGsort sub { $_[0] < $_[1] }, @list;
01528     PGsort sub { $_[0] lt $_[1] }, @list;
01529 
01530 (called num_sort and lex_sort) provide slightly slower, but safer, routines for the PG language. 
01531 (The subroutines for ordering are B<required>. Note the commas!)
01532 
01533 =cut
01534 
01535 # This sort can cause troubles because of its special use of $a and $b
01536 # Putting it in dangerousMacros.pl worked frequently, but not always.
01537 # In particular ANS( ans_eva1 ans_eval2) caused trouble.
01538 # One answer at a time did not --- very strange.
01539 # This was replaced by a quick sort routine because the original subroutine
01540 # did not work with Safe when Perl was built with ithreads
01541 
01542 #sub PGsort {
01543 #   my $sort_order = shift;
01544 #   die "Must supply an ordering function with PGsort: PGsort sub {\$a cmp \$b }, \@list\n" unless ref($sort_order) eq 'CODE';
01545 #   sort {&$sort_order($a,$b)} @_;
01546 #}
01547 
01548       # quicksort
01549 sub PGsort {
01550          my $cmp = shift;
01551      die "Must supply an ordering function with PGsort: PGsort  sub {\$_[0]  < \$_[1] }, \@list\n" unless ref($cmp) eq 'CODE';
01552          if (@_ == 0) { return () }
01553          else {
01554            my $b_item = shift;
01555            my ($small, $large);
01556            my $a_item;
01557            for $a_item (@_) {
01558              push @{&$cmp($a_item, $b_item) ? $small : $large}, $a_item;
01559            }
01560            return (PGsort($cmp, @$small), $b_item, PGsort($cmp, @$large));
01561          }
01562        }
01563 
01564 
01565 =head2 includePGtext
01566 
01567     includePGtext($string_ref, $envir_ref)
01568 
01569 Calls C<createPGtext> recursively with the $safeCompartment variable set to 0
01570 so that the rendering continues in the current safe compartment.  The output
01571 is the same as the output from createPGtext. This is used in processing
01572 some of the sample CAPA files.
01573 
01574 =cut
01575 
01576 #this is a method for importing additional PG files from within one PG file.
01577 # sub includePGtext {
01578 #     my $self = shift;
01579 #     my $string_ref =shift;
01580 #     my $envir_ref = shift;
01581 #     $self->environment($envir_ref);
01582 #   $self->createPGtext($string_ref);
01583 # }
01584 # evaluation macros
01585 
01586 
01587 
01588 no strict;   # this is important -- I guess because eval operates on code which is not written with strict in mind.
01589 
01590 
01591 
01592 =head2 PG_restricted_eval
01593 
01594     PG_restricted_eval($string)
01595 
01596 Evaluated in package 'main'. Result of last statement is returned.
01597 When called from within a safe compartment the safe compartment package
01598 is 'main'.
01599 
01600 
01601 =cut
01602 
01603 # Remember, eval STRING evaluates code in the current lexical context, so any
01604 # lexicals available here will also be available in the evaluated code. So we
01605 # move the actual eval into a helper function called PG_restricted_eval_helper,
01606 # which doesn't need to have any lexicals.
01607 sub PG_restricted_eval {
01608     my $string = shift;
01609     my $out = PG_restricted_eval_helper($string);
01610     my $err = $@;
01611     my $err_report = $err if $err =~ /\S/;
01612     return wantarray ? ($out, $err, $err_report) : $out;
01613 }
01614 
01615 # This is a helper that doesn't use any lexicals. See above.
01616 sub PG_restricted_eval_helper {
01617     no strict;
01618     local $SIG{__WARN__} = "DEFAULT";
01619     local $SIG{__DIE__} = "DEFAULT";
01620     return eval("package main;\n" . $_[0]);
01621 }
01622 
01623 sub PG_macro_file_eval {      # would like to modify this so that it requires use strict on the files that it evaluates.
01624     my $string = shift;
01625     my ($pck,$file,$line) = caller;
01626     
01627     local $SIG{__WARN__} = "DEFAULT";
01628     local $SIG{__DIE__} = "DEFAULT";
01629     
01630     no strict;
01631     my $out = eval  ("package main; be_strict();\n" . $string );
01632     my $errors =$@;
01633     my $full_error_report = "PG_macro_file_eval detected error at line $line of file $file \n"
01634                 . $errors .
01635                 "The calling package is $pck\n" if defined($errors) && $errors =~/\S/;
01636     use strict;
01637     
01638     return (wantarray) ?  ($out, $errors,$full_error_report) : $out;
01639 }
01640 =head2 PG_answer_eval
01641 
01642 
01643     PG_answer_eval($string)
01644 
01645 Evaluated in package defined by the current safe compartment.
01646 Result of last statement is returned.
01647 When called from within a safe compartment the safe compartment package
01648 is 'main'.
01649 
01650 There is still some confusion about how these two evaluation subroutines work
01651 and how best to define them.  It is useful to have two evaluation procedures
01652 since at some point one might like to make the answer evaluations more stringent.
01653 
01654 =cut
01655 
01656 
01657 sub PG_answer_eval {
01658    local($string) = shift;   # I made this local just in case -- see PG_restricted_eval
01659    my $errors = '';
01660    my $full_error_report = '';
01661    my ($pck,$file,$line) = caller; 
01662     # Because of the global variable $PG::compartment_name and $PG::safe_cmpt
01663     # only one problem safe compartment can be active at a time.
01664     # This might cause problems at some point.  In that case a cleverer way
01665     # of insuring that the package stays in scope until the answer is evaluated
01666     # will be required.
01667     
01668     # This is pretty tricky and doesn't always work right.
01669     # We seem to need PG_priv instead of main when PG_answer_eval is called within a completion
01670     # 'package PG_priv; '
01671     
01672         local $SIG{__WARN__} = sub {die(@_)};  # make warn die, so all errors are reported.
01673     local $SIG{__DIE__} = "DEFAULT";
01674     
01675     no strict;
01676     my $out = eval('package main;'.$string);
01677     $out = '' unless defined($out);
01678     $errors .= $@;
01679     $full_error_report = "ERROR: at line $line of file $file
01680                 $errors
01681                 The calling package is $pck\n" if defined($errors) && $errors =~/\S/;
01682     use strict;
01683     
01684     return (wantarray) ?  ($out, $errors,$full_error_report) : $out;
01685 
01686 
01687 }
01688 
01689 # sub original_preprocess_code {
01690 #   my $evalString = shift;
01691 #   # BEGIN_TEXT and END_TEXT must occur on a line by themselves.
01692 #   $evalString =~ s/\n\s*END_TEXT[\s;]*\n/\nEND_TEXT\n/g;
01693 #   $evalString =~ s/\n\s*BEGIN_TEXT[\s;]*\n/\nTEXT\(EV3\(<<'END_TEXT'\)\);\n/g;
01694 #   $evalString =~ s/ENDDOCUMENT.*/ENDDOCUMENT();/s; # remove text after ENDDOCUMENT
01695 # 
01696 #   $evalString =~ s/\\/\\\\/g;    # \ can't be used for escapes because of TeX conflict
01697 #   $evalString =~ s/~~/\\/g;      # use ~~ as escape instead, use # for comments
01698 #   $evalString;
01699 # }
01700 sub default_preprocess_code {
01701     my $evalString = shift;
01702     # BEGIN_TEXT and END_TEXT must occur on a line by themselves.
01703     $evalString =~ s/\n\s*END_TEXT[\s;]*\n/\nEND_TEXT\n/g;
01704     $evalString =~ s/\n\s*END_PGML[\s;]*\n/\nEND_PGML\n/g;
01705     $evalString =~ s/\n\s*END_PGML_SOLUTION[\s;]*\n/\nEND_PGML_SOLUTION\n/g;
01706     $evalString =~ s/\n\s*END_PGML_HINT[\s;]*\n/\nEND_PGML_HINT\n/g;
01707     $evalString =~ s/\n\s*END_SOLUTION[\s;]*\n/\nEND_SOLUTION\n/g;
01708     $evalString =~ s/\n\s*END_HINT[\s;]*\n/\nEND_HINT\n/g;
01709     $evalString =~ s/\n\s*BEGIN_TEXT[\s;]*\n/\nTEXT\(EV3P\(<<'END_TEXT'\)\);\n/g;
01710     $evalString =~ s/\n\s*BEGIN_PGML[\s;]*\n/\nTEXT\(PGML::Format2\(<<'END_PGML'\)\);\n/g;
01711     $evalString =~ s/\n\s*BEGIN_PGML_SOLUTION[\s;]*\n/\nSOLUTION\(PGML::Format2\(<<'END_PGML_SOLUTION'\)\);\n/g;
01712     $evalString =~ s/\n\s*BEGIN_PGML_HINT[\s;]*\n/\nHINT\(PGML::Format2\(<<'END_PGML_SOLUTION'\)\);\n/g;
01713     $evalString =~ s/\n\s*BEGIN_SOLUTION[\s;]*\n/\nSOLUTION\(EV3P\(<<'END_SOLUTION'\)\);\n/g;
01714     $evalString =~ s/\n\s*BEGIN_HINT[\s;]*\n/\nHINT\(EV3P\(<<'END_HINT'\)\);\n/g;
01715     $evalString =~ s/ENDDOCUMENT.*/ENDDOCUMENT();/s; # remove text after ENDDOCUMENT
01716 
01717     $evalString =~ s/\\/\\\\/g;    # \ can't be used for escapes because of TeX conflict
01718     $evalString =~ s/~~/\\/g;      # use ~~ as escape instead, use # for comments
01719     $evalString;
01720 }
01721 sub default_postprocess_code {
01722     my $evalString_ref = shift;
01723     $evalString_ref;
01724 }
01725 
01726 sub dumpvar {
01727     my ($packageName) = @_;
01728 
01729     local(*alias);
01730     
01731     sub emit {
01732         print @_;
01733     }
01734     
01735     *stash = *{"${packageName}::"};
01736     $, = "  ";
01737     
01738     emit "Content-type: text/html\n\n<PRE>\n";
01739     
01740     
01741     while ( ($varName, $globValue) = each %stash) {
01742         emit "$varName\n";
01743         
01744     *alias = $globValue;
01745     next if $varName=~/main/;
01746     
01747     #if (defined($alias) ) {  # get rid of defined since this is deprecated
01748     if ($alias ) {
01749         emit "  \$$varName $alias \n";
01750     }
01751     
01752     if ( @alias) {
01753         emit "  \@$varName @alias \n";
01754     }
01755     if (%alias ) {
01756         emit "  %$varName \n";
01757         foreach $key (keys %alias) {
01758             emit "    $key => $alias{$key}\n";
01759         }
01760 
01761 
01762 
01763     }
01764     }
01765     emit "</PRE></PRE>";
01766 
01767 
01768 }
01769 use strict;
